title: Images scaled by the browser
desc: Never scale images in the browser, that will slow down the rendering.

title: Cache Time
desc: How long time the assets are cached in the browser. Long time is good.

title: Critical Rendering Path Score
desc: Do as little as possible within the HEAD tag so that the browser can start rendering a page as soon as possible (avoid DNS lookups and load CSS/JS files).

title: Number of CSS images per page
desc: Few larger CSS images are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

title: Number of CSS files per page
desc: Few larger files are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

title: CSS Weight
desc: The weight of CSS is important, because of mobile and networks, keep the size to a minimal.

title: CSS File Weight Per Page
desc: Do not download large front-end CSS farmework when you only use small parts of it.

title: Document Weight
desc: Keep the document at a reasonable size, it will make it possible for the browser to generate the page faster.

title: Number of DOM elements
desc: Too many DOM elements means that the page is complex and will be slower to render

title: Number of font files per page
desc: Few larger files are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

title: Number of images per page
desc: Avoid too many images because it will take time for them all to load.

title: Image Weight
desc: The weight of images is important, are usually 60-70% of the total page weight

title: Images Weight Per Page
desc: Image weight are the largest part of a web page. Make sure they are compressed and as small as possible.

title: Number of JS files per page
desc: Few larger files are better when using HTTP 1.1. For HTTP 2.0 it is better with many small files from few domains.

title: Number of JS synchronously inside head
desc: Loading Javascript synchronously inside of the HEAD tag will slow down your page rendering. Just don't do it!

title: JS Weight
desc: The weight of javascripts is important, because of mobile and networks, keep the size to a minimal.

title: JS File Weight Per Page
desc: Don't download large Javascript libraries when you only use small parts of it.

title: Max requests per domain
desc: Using HTTP 1.1 you want to avoid loading too many assets from one domain

title: Remove duplicate JS and CSS
desc: It is bad practice include the same js or css twice since browsers will execute the code each toim

title: Number Of Domains
desc: Many domains means many DNS lookups and that means slower pages.

title: Total page weight (including all assets)
desc: The total size is really important because of slow mobile networks, keep the size small.

title: Pages with SPOF
desc: How many pages have a single point of failures (meaning if someone elses API/site is broken, it will break your page.

title: Redirects Per Page
desc: Avoid doing redirects, it will slow down the page!

title: Number of requests per page
desc: Fewer requests are always faster than many requests.

title: Requests Without Expires
desc: Requests shall always have expire headers, so that they can be cached by the browser

title: Requests without GZip
desc: All text content (JS/CSS/HTML) can and should be sent GZiped so that the size is as small as possible.

title: Rule Score
desc: The sitespeed.io total rule score for all the pages

title: Domains with only one request
desc: Many domains means many DNS lookups and that means slower pages. Only loading one request for one domain is wasteful.

title: Number of SPOF per page
desc: A Single Point Of Failure is a asset that is loaded (usually) from another domain before the page starts rendering, meaning if the asset isn not loaded, the page will be broken/slow.

title: Time since last modification
desc: The time since a file was changed the last time. If it was long ago, please make sure the cache time is high!

title: backEndTime
desc: The time it takes for the network and the server to generate and start sending the HTML. Definition: responseStart - navigationStart

title: backEndTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: domContentLoadedTime
desc: The time the browser takes to parse the document and execute deferred and parser-inserted scripts including the network time from the users location to your server. Definition: domContentLoadedEventStart - navigationStart

title: domContentLoadedTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: domInteractiveTime
desc: The time the browser takes to parse the document, including the network time from the users location to your server. Definition: domInteractive - navigationStart

title: domInteractiveTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: domainLookupTime
desc: The time it takes to do the DNS lookup. Definition: domainLookupEnd - domainLookupStart

title: domainLookupTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: frontEndTime
desc: The time it takes for the browser to parse and create the page. Definition: loadEventStart - responseEnd

title: frontEndTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: pageDownloadTime
desc: How long time does it take to download the page (the HTML). Definition: responseEnd - responseStart

title: pageDownloadTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: pageLoadTime
desc: The time it takes for page to load, from initiation of the pageview (e.g., click on a page link) to load completion in the browser. Important: this is only relevant to some pages, depending on how you page is built. Definition: loadEventStart - navigationStart

title: pageLoadTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: redirectionTime
desc: Time spent on redirects. Definition: fetchStart - navigationStart

title: redirectionTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: serverConnectionTime
desc: How long time it takes to connect to the server. Definition: connectEnd - connectStart

title: serverConnectionTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: serverResponseTime
desc: How long time does it take until the server respond. Definition: responseStart - requestStart

title: serverResponseTimeChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: speedIndex
desc: Speed Index calculated with the RUM Speed Index

title: speedIndexChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: firstPaint
desc: This is when the first paint happens on the screen. If the browser support this metric, we use that. Else we use the time of the last non-async script or css from the head.

title: firstPaintChrome
desc: User Timing API metric

title: blocked time
desc: Time spent in a queue waiting for a network connection

title: dns time
desc: The time required to resolve a host name

title: connect time
desc: Time required to create TCP connection

title: ssl time
desc: Time required for SSL/TLS negotiation

title: send time
desc: Time required to send HTTP request to the server

title: wait time
desc: Waiting for a response from the server

title: receive time
desc: Time required to read entire response from the server (or cache).
